reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central aspect of the post’s practical conclusion—i.e., that holding “compute” fixed won’t meaningfully slow an early software intelligence explosion—by arguing that the post’s two-input framing (compute vs cognitive labor) ignores other potentially binding complements (data, infra, bandwidth, energy, eval/red-teaming, coordination) that could cap effective experimentation and thus slow progress early. If true, that would meaningfully weaken the post’s optimism about early-stage acceleration without more ‘hardware’ broadly construed, though it doesn’t strictly refute the narrower claim that FLOP-compute itself needn’t be the binding constraint. The argument is plausible and mostly correct, but remains generic: it doesn’t show these other bottlenecks are likely to bind strongly enough to mimic a hard ceiling, nor does it engage the post’s key moves (e.g., substituting toward cheaper experiments, algorithmic efficiency increasing #experiments, extrapolation concerns with CES). The critique is clear, focused on one theme, and contains little filler.
title: Non-compute bottlenecks may limit acceleration even with abundant cognitive labor
